title: 103_hr3300
content: The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act of 1960, which promotes wildlife conservation on military reservations. SEC. 3. INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR MILITARY INSTALLATIONS. Section 101(a) (16 U.S.C. 670a(a)) is amended to require the Secretary to prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for each military installation in the United States. The Secretary must prepare integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, except when deemed inappropriate. Amendments include changing "cooperative plan" to "integrated natural resource management plan." The Secretary must prepare integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, except when deemed inappropriate. Amendments include changing "cooperative plan" to "integrated natural resource management plan" in various sections of the legislation. In various sections of the legislation, "cooperative plans" are amended to "integrated natural resource management plans." In legislation, "cooperative plans" are changed to "integrated natural resource management plans" in multiple sections. In legislation, "cooperative plans" are replaced with "integrated natural resource management plans" in various sections, including wetland protection and restoration. The legislation replaces "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" in various sections, including wetland protection and restoration. It also includes wetland creation for fish or wildlife support, conservation needs for biological communities, and specific natural resource management goals and timeframes for proposed actions. The legislation replaces "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" and includes wetland creation for fish or wildlife support, conservation needs for biological communities, and specific natural resource management goals and timeframes for proposed actions. It addresses fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation for military installations. The legislation aims to address the needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation on military installations while ensuring no net loss in capability to support the military mission. It also provides for sustained public use of natural resources, as long as it does not conflict with the military mission. The legislation aims to address the needs for fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation on military installations while ensuring no net loss in capability to support the military mission. It also provides for sustained public use of natural resources, professional enforcement of natural resource laws and regulations, and public access to the installation. The legislation aims to address fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation on military installations. It ensures no net loss in capability to support the military mission, sustained public use of natural resources, professional enforcement of natural resource laws, and public access to the installation. Additionally, the Secretary of Defense must provide an opportunity for public comment on each integrated natural resource management plan. The legislation requires a review of military installations for the preparation of integrated natural resource management plans. The Secretary of each military department must review all military installations in the United States to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. This report must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense within 9 months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Defense must review military installations to determine the need for natural resource management plans. A report must be submitted to Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Defense must review military installations to determine the need for natural resource management plans. A report must be submitted to Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The report will list installations where an integrated natural resource management plan is not deemed appropriate, along with explanations for each. The deadline for these plans is 2 years after the report submission. The Secretary of Defense must prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for military installations within 2 years after submitting a report to Congress listing installations where such plans are deemed appropriate. The resource management plan must be prepared and implemented in collaboration with the Secretary of the Interior and appropriate State agencies, as required by the Sikes Act. For military installations with existing cooperative plans, negotiations must be completed for necessary changes to align with the new requirements. The Sikes Act requires completion of negotiations with the Secretary of the Interior and State agencies for changes to the natural resource plan. The Secretary of Defense must allow public comments on proposed integrated resource management plans and changes to cooperative plans. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is amended to include a new subsection (g) requiring the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually by March 1. The report must include the number of plans in effect for the year. The Secretary of Defense must review and report annually on integrated natural resource management plans, including the number of plans in effect and the amount of money spent on conservation activities. The Secretary of Defense must annually review and report on the number of integrated natural resource management plans in effect and the funds spent on conservation activities, including those under the Legacy Resource Management Program. An assessment of plan compliance with specific requirements is also included. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with State agencies, must submit a report by March 1 each year on the compliance of natural resource management plans with specific requirements to ensure no net loss of lands for military missions. The Secretary of the Interior must submit a report by March 1 each year on the amount of money spent by the Department of the Interior and State agencies on conservation activities under integrated natural resource management plans to the Committees on Merchant Marine and Fisheries and Armed Services. The report on conservation spending under integrated natural resource management plans must be submitted annually to specific congressional committees. SEC. 6 amends Title I to allow the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws on conservation of natural resources on military installations. SEC. 7 addresses natural resource management services. The Secretary of Defense can enforce Federal laws on conservation of natural resources on military installations within the United States. Additionally, natural resource management services are addressed in Title I. SEC. 7. NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT SERVICES: The Secretary of each military department must ensure trained personnel for natural resource management and law enforcement to comply with the Act. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. Title I is further amended by inserting after section 107 the following: "SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS." The term 'military department' refers to the Department of the Army, Navy, and Air Force. 'Military installation' includes land owned by the US and administered by the Secretary of Defense or a military department, including public lands reserved for defense use. The term 'State fish and wildlife agency' refers to a State government agency responsible for managing fish and wildlife resources. The term 'United States' includes States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. The term 'State fish and wildlife agency' refers to a State government agency responsible for managing fish or wildlife resources. The term 'United States' includes States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and territories and possessions. SEC. 9. SHORT TITLE. Title I (16 U.S.C. 670a et seq.) is further amended by inserting after section 108 the following: "SEC. 109. SHORT TITLE. This title may be cited as the 'Sikes Act'." SEC. 10. COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. Cost Sharing.--Section 103a(b) is amended by replacing "matching basis" with "cost-sharing basis". Accounting.--Section 103a(c) is amended by adding ", and shall not be subject to section 1535 of that title". SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 is repealed. SEC. 11. REPEAL. Section 2 of the Act of October 27, 1986 (Public Law 99-651; 16 U.S.C. 670a-1) is repealed. SEC. 12. CLERICAL AMENDMENTS. Title I, as amended by this Act, is further amended by changing references from "military reservations" to "military installations" in various sections. In Title I, references to "military reservations" are changed to "military installations" in various sections, including the renaming of locations in subparagraphs and sections. In Title I, references to "military reservations" are changed to "military installations" in various sections, including the renaming of locations in subparagraphs and sections by striking and inserting specific terms. SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends sections related to programs on military installations and public lands by updating authorization years to 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997. Passed the House of Representatives on September 12, 1994. HR 3300 RS----2 was passed by the House of Representatives on September 12, 1994.
